questions.question_text: An IT director wants to strengthen the process for how wireless users authenticate after a recent security audit in which an evil-twin attack compromised domain administrator accounts. Which of the following will the director MOST likely implement?

discussion.content: EAP-TLS....quick way to remember the correct answer using the "E"AP-"T"LS for Evil Twin

questions.question_text: A recent audit found that passwords are being sent in a cleartext manner during CLI authentication. The network team has been tasked to manage all network devices using secure methods. Which of the following will the network team MOST likely enable on the network devices?

discussion.content: CLI = Command Line Interface; I actually had to look this one up.

The question is on software additional functionality, which of course most printers can perform these functions. It is assumed the device software is already installed. The trick here is the keyword 'update' not 'install'. So C goes well in that respect.

comments.content: I disagree. The printer drivers are all that is needed to print, even the basic OS version will print. You can't scan with printer drivers, you need the additional scanning and faxing software. I can plug in an MFD to Windows, and the OS will install the Microsoft drivers for it to print with, no scanning or faxing ability until you install the full suite of software.

discussion.content: I'm pretty sure whoever came up with this question crawled out of Satan's rectum with the sole intention of being a fiery hot turd, and succeeding very adequately...
It's a new device which mean firmware need to be updated anyway.

This question is silly.

A. Device software
The key is update. Update software would unlikely give extra feature like this.
B. Printer drivers
Printer drivers are for printing, not scanning or faxing.
C. Printer firmware
Although this does not make sense, in the world on CompTia it is the only update that could allow this function. For example, think that firmware was placed on the printer to allow access like print on demand or some other control software. In order to allow additional functions your would need to update the firmware to allow extra functions. If you think as the firmware as low-level security on the printer, you would need to enable or configure it to allow this to take place.
D. NIC drivers
If they can already print, the drivers are going fine.

Drivers makes no sense. PRINTER drivers do nothing for scanning/faxing.
Firmware isn't it. A multi-purpose device that was designed for printing/faxing/scanning wouldn't ship with a firmware incapable of doing those things.
Device software installed on the computers needing to accomplish the tasks other than printing, such as scanning/faxing, makes the most sense.

i guess when it said printer drivers i was thinking of the printer's smart card drivers for scan to email instead of literal print drivers only for printing... CompTIA, you have claimed another victim.
it should be the printer firmware

Updating the firmware doesn't make any sense. "Firmware is software installed on a small memory chip on a hardware device" Why should I update a new multifunction device's firmware? Even the OS sees the printer as plug and play network printer, I need to set up scan and fax drivers first. Then, set up Their software if clients don't use third-party software for scanning.

comments.content: But we also update drivers too, don't we??

discussion.content: Keyword update that goes with firmware.
Such a stupid question, the correct answer is C but in the real world it makes no absolute sense.
how is this not drivers?

This answer makes no sense. Why would a multifunction printer have a scanner that is not supported by its firmware? Besides, faxing and scanning done from a computer as clearly stated in the question is done via software, so the answer should be A

Why would the non-updated firmware of "multi-function" devices not have the basic multi-function abilities already there? You need the software for that--but of course...they said "updating" so all bets are off as to which way to guess their intetions. Gotta love so many questions that have nothing to do with network knowledge, just the ability to parse horribly worded trick questions.

comments.content: Was thinking the same thing.. why wouldn't the firmware already allow for the intended functionalities of the multifunction device? That makes no sense. I've never heard of such a thing.

discussion.content: i was leaning towards A myself, however re reading the question notice the word functionality... and not option... that i feel is the trick..... firmware would give you access to more functions of that device while the software would give users the option to use those additional functions

My leaning was C but I went with A because a MFD is not just a printer. Even though it's sometimes called a multi functional printer(MFP) it's actually a printer, fax machine, and scanner so to say you're updated the printers firmware seems incorrect. If answer C was MFD firmware instead of Printer Firmware it would be a easy answer.
Shouldn't it be A - device software, this would allow users to scan and fax.

comments.content: Yes it should be device software

questions.question_text: A company recently upgraded all of its printers to networked multifunction devices. Users can print to the new devices, but they would also like the ability to scan and fax files from their computers. Which of the following should the technician update to allow this functionality?
Which of the following physical security measures will BEST identify authorized individuals who should be allowed access?

discussion.content: Physical should be replaced by physiological

comments.content: Agreed, physical security is not Something You Are.

questions.question_text: A company has moved to a building with a large number of WLANs. All clients are 802.11b/g/n capable. Which of the following can be performed to reduce the chance of interference with the nearby APs and maintain or improve the performance of the wireless clients?

discussion.content: Because the existing NIC cards support both 2.4 and 5.0. The gist is to move to the less crowded spectrum (5.0) and if they turn off the 2.4 on their WAPs and use only the 5.0, they accomplishing the goal without replacing anything or spending any money.
Is it not A?
